abstract_summ: We did not observe any differences in inpatient management, including place of care and pharmacological management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) CONCLUSION: Incident AHF hospitalization significantly declined in our centre during the COVID‐19 pandemic, but hospitalized patients had more severe symptoms at admission.RESULTS When compared to the preceding months, during the COVID pandemic there was a 56.5% reduction in the ER visits and a 46.9% reduction in hospital admissions, without an increase in mortality (9 patients died in both time periods).AIMS: To evaluate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on patient admissions to Italian cardiac care units (CCUs).AIMS: To examine the impact of COVID‐19 on acute heart failure (AHF) hospitalization rates, clinical characteristics and management of patients admitted to a tertiary Heart Failure Unit in London during the peak of the pandemic.Conclusions During the first phase of the COVID-19 pandemic, there was a marked decline in acute cardiovascular hospitalizations and patients who were admitted had shorter lengths of stay.
title_summ: Heart Failure in the Time of COVID-19.Heart Disease Deaths during the Covid-19 PandemicNo Evidence for Reduced Hospital Admissions or Increased Deaths from Stroke or Heart Attack During COVID-19Reduction of hospitalizations for myocardial infarction in Italy in the COVID-19 era31 days of COVID-19—cardiac events during restriction of public life—a comparative studyThe impact of COVID‐19 on heart failure hospitalization and management: report from a Heart Failure Unit in London during the peak of the pandemicDeclines in Hospitalizations for Acute Cardiovascular Conditions During the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Multicenter Tertiary Care ExperienceReductions in Heart Failure Hospitalizations During the COVID-19 PandemicWorrying decrease in hospital admissions for myocardial infarction during the COVID-19 pandemicDecrease in acute coronary syndrome presentations during the COVID19 pandemic in upstate New YorkImpact of Coronavirus Disease 2019 outbreak on acute coronary syndrome admissions: four weeks to reverse the trend
title_abstract_phrases: We did not observe any differences in inpatient management, including place of care and pharmacological management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) CONCLUSION: Incident AHF hospitalization significantly declined in our centre during the COVID‐19 pandemic, but hospitalized patients had more severe symptoms at admission.Reduction of hospitalizations for myocardial infarction in Italy in the COVID-19 eraAIMS: To evaluate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on patient admissions to Italian cardiac care units (CCUs).Declines in Hospitalizations for Acute Cardiovascular Conditions During the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Multicenter Tertiary Care ExperienceAbstract Background While patients with cardiovascular disease face excess risks of severe illness with coronavirus disease-2019 (COVID-19), there may be indirect consequences of the pandemic on this high-risk patient segment.The impact of COVID‐19 on heart failure hospitalization and management: report from a Heart Failure Unit in London during the peak of the pandemicAIMS: To examine the impact of COVID‐19 on acute heart failure (AHF) hospitalization rates, clinical characteristics and management of patients admitted to a tertiary Heart Failure Unit in London during the peak of the pandemic.Conclusions During the first phase of the COVID-19 pandemic, there was a marked decline in acute cardiovascular hospitalizations and patients who were admitted had shorter lengths of stay.
